I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed policy-

1. 
based loan to Mongolia for the Social Welfare Support Program Phase 2.1 
 
2. 
The main objective of the program is to protect funding for social welfare programs for the 
poor and vulnerable people in Mongolia during the implementation of an extended fund facility of 
the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The program will implement policy actions to improve fiscal 
policy management, and to better target and consolidate social welfare programs. These reforms 
will help make funding for social welfare programs more sustainable, and increase their efficiency 
and effectiveness. 
 

II. 

THE PROGRAM 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
Development problems and opportunities. During a period of rapid economic growth 
between  2004  and  2014,  Mongolia  expanded  its  social  welfare  programs  through  large  fiscal 
surpluses and distributed mining income. Social transfers, which account for about 40% of the 
income of poor people, have significantly reduced poverty in Mongolia. Since 2010, poverty has 
declined by 17 percentage points to 21.6% in 2014. Nevertheless, 35% of the population with a 
monthly per capita consumption of MNT150,000–MNT250,000 in 2014 were living just above the 
2014 poverty line of MNT146,500 per month. They were particularly vulnerable to shocks and at 
risk of falling back into poverty. 
 
4. 
Since 2015, Mongolia’s economic situation has deteriorated further. The gross domestic 
product (GDP) growth rate declined to 1% in 2016, and unemployment increased to 8.6% at the 
end of 2016. The economic slowdown and poor fiscal management—in particular, excessive off-
budget spending leading up to the general election  in June 2016—contributed to the widening 
fiscal deficit. On 9 August 2016, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) informed the nation that Mongolia 
was  facing  serious  fiscal  challenges.  The  fiscal  deficit  reached  15.4%  of  GDP  in  2016.  The 
expanding  fiscal  deficit  also  worsened  Mongolia’s  debt  situation—general  government  debt 
increased from  59.5%  of  GDP to  83.7%  of GDP in 2016.  In  addition,  continued  weak  external 
demand  and  the  sharp  drop  in  commodity  prices  widened  the  current  account  deficit  and  put 
pressure on the balance of payments. 
 
5. 
The government recognizes that if the current  internal and external imbalances are not 
managed  effectively,  the  country  could  face  an  economic  crisis.  In  response,  the  government 
crafted an economic recovery program in consultation with key development partners to stabilize 
the economy at the macro level, reduce debt burden in the medium term, restore foreign investors’ 
confidence, and diversify the economy.2 The government is committed to reducing the fiscal deficit 
gradually in line with the Fiscal Stability Law amended in 2016. However, given the dire situation 
of the economy, the government also sought assistance from the IMF. On 19 February 2017, the 
government and the IMF reached an agreement on an extended fund facility to (i) improve fiscal 
policy  management,  (ii)  improve  monetary  and  central  bank  governance,  (iii)  strengthen  the

2 The economic recovery program was approved by the Parliament on 24 November 2016. 

 2 

banking system and preserve financial stability, and (iv) boost competitiveness and diversify the 
economy. 

6. 
As a result of the fiscal situation, funding for some social welfare programs was reduced 
in  2016,  and  a  further  10%  reduction  in  the  funding  for  social  welfare  programs  for  2017  was 
reflected in the 2017 state budget. Furthermore, budget deficits will be reduced steadily as part 
of the fiscal consolidation process under the extended fund facility. This could reverse the poverty 
reduction gains  by  creating  new  poor  and  bringing  into  poverty  those that  crossed the  poverty 
line.  It  is  estimated  that  the  poverty  rate  would  be  about  10  percentage  points  higher  in  the 
absence  of  social  welfare  programs.3  Therefore,  the  proposed  phase  2  of  the  Social  Welfare 
Support Program will support social welfare programs for the poor and vulnerable during fiscal 
consolidation. 
 
7. 
Challenges of social welfare in Mongolia. Social welfare in Mongolia is an integral part 
of social protection, which consists of both cash transfers and services.4 Social welfare programs 
in Mongolia are designed to support the elderly, disabled, and the poor and vulnerable people. 
The  Ministry  of  Labor  and  Social  Protection  (MLSP)  administers  71  social  welfare  programs, 
which can be grouped into the following broad categories:5 social welfare pensions; social welfare 
allowance;  community-based  welfare  services;  allowance  for  the  elderly  with  state  merit; 
allowance for the elderly; allowance for the disabled; allowance for mothers and children; food 
stamp  program  (FSP); 6  and  child  money  program  (CMP).7  FSP  and  CMP  provide  significant 
support to the poor. For instance, the poverty rate in 2014 would have been 3 percentage points 
higher, at 24.6%, without the CMP.8 In addition, over 50% of the welfare beneficiaries are women, 
except for the  beneficiaries of  allowance for  the elderly  with state  merits,  where only  18%  are 
women.9 
 
8. 
As discussed in phase 1 of the ADB support program, Mongolia’s current social welfare 
programs  are  (i) fragmented,  leading  to  duplication  of  benefits  and  high  administrative  and 
implementation costs; and (ii) wide in coverage and targeted by category, which is costly because 
some of the recipients are not poor. For example, nonpoor beneficiaries comprise a large share 
of  welfare  program  recipients:  about  50%  of  those  receiving  social  welfare  pensions  and 
allowance, 61.8% of those receiving allowance for the disabled, 69.6% of CMP recipients, 73.2% 
of community-based welfare service recipients, 72% of those receiving allowance for mothers and 
children, 85.2% of those receiving allowance for the elderly, and 95.4% of those receiving social 
welfare  allowance  for  the  elderly  with  state  merit  (see  footnote  9).  The  benefit  level  is  also 
inadequate  for  the  poor.  Hence,  the  current  social  welfare  system  is  not  effective  enough  in 
protecting  the  poor  and  vulnerable  people,  especially  during  an  economic  downturn.  It  is

welfare programs. 

 
9. 
ADB support for social welfare reform. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been 
at  the  forefront  of  social  welfare  reform  in  Mongolia  since  2001,10 including  support  for  (i)  the 
introduction of  proxy  means testing  to target the  poor,  (ii) the  cancellation of  several  universal 
benefits considered poorly targeted,11 (iii) the introduction of the food stamp program as the first 
poverty-targeted benefit in Mongolia, and (iv) the passage of the amended Social Welfare Law in 
January 2012, which legalized the reforms.12 ADB supports the government’s strategic vision to 
further modernize the social welfare system through improved targeting, consolidation of benefits, 
and financial sustainability. 
 
10. 
Progress  made  under  phase  1  of  the  Social  Welfare  Support  Program.  Through 
phase  1  of  the  program, ADB  helped  the  government  take  the  necessary  initial  steps  toward 
improving  and  expanding  targeting,  and  consolidating  various  social  welfare  programs.  For 
instance, the government  took the following  policy  actions to strengthen targeting:  (i)  issued a 
resolution  to  use  the  poverty-targeted  integrated  household  information  database  across 
government  programs;  (ii)  allocated  funding  to  update  the  poverty-targeted  database;  and 
(iii) prepared a draft resolution requiring the Ministry of Justice and Ministry of Education to adopt 
proxy means testing to provide free legal services and secondary school textbooks to the poorest 
households. In addition, funding for the FSP increased by 80%, which expanded both benefit and 
coverage.  The  government  also  took  steps  to  support  consolidation  by  establishing  an 
interministerial working group to analyze the options for the consolidation of welfare benefits.13 
Phase 1 also helped draft the future heritage law to establish a sovereign wealth fund. 
 
11. 
Lessons  learned  and  the  government’s  commitment  to  reforms.  On  fiscal  policy 
management, phase 1 helped improve budget transparency, supported fiscal consolidation, and 
drafted a law to establish the Future Heritage Fund (i.e., sovereign wealth fund). However, the 
program placed less emphasis on strengthening the fiscal framework. Furthermore, it was difficult 
to anticipate the  excessive spending  of the  previous government  in  the  lead-up to the general 
election in June 2016. The differences between phases 1 and 2 of the program are that (i) the 
new  government  is  committed  to  fiscal  reforms,  and  (ii)  an  IMF-led  program  is  in  place.  For 
instance, the government has taken the following policy actions:

12. 
In addition, policy actions to support fiscal consolidation and improve the fiscal framework 
under  the  IMF-led  program  include  (i)  making  personal  income  tax  more  progressive,  (ii) 
preventing Bank of Mongolia from engaging in additional quasi-fiscal activity, (iii) reforming law 
on concession projects, (iv) rationalizing and better aligning the public investment program with 
national  development  priorities,  (v)  creating  a  fiscal  council  to  provide  independent  budget 
forecasts and costings of new policy proposals, (vi) granting the government the sole authority to 
determine  the  total  amount  of  spending  in  the  budget,  and  (vii)  granting  MOF  the  authority  to 
approve proposals to the cabinet that have a budgetary cost.15 
 
13. 
On  social  welfare,  the  new  government  is  committed  to  social  welfare  reform  as 
highlighted in the development policy letter in Appendix 3. The government aims to improve the 
effectiveness  of  the  CMP  by  introducing  targeting  to  60%  of  the  children  in  Mongolia,  where 
eligibility guidelines were developed and issued by MLSP. In the past, the CMP was not a well-
targeted program and a large percentage of the nonpoor were also accessing it. The government 
also incorporated funding for the CMP into the 2017 state budget, and reflected the CMP in the 
Social  Welfare  Law  amended  in  2016.  This  amended  law  introduced  additional  needs-based 
eligibility criteria for allowance for caregivers. In addition, the Law on Social Welfare for the Elderly 
was amended in 2017, and the new Law on Allowance with State  Merits was approved by the 
Parliament also in 2017. This would enable the allowance for elderly with state merits, a merit-
based entitlement, to be removed from the welfare budget in the future. 
 
14. 
Further social welfare reform is needed. Despite the progress made so far, the reform 
agenda is far from complete. While phase 1 of the ADB program established the policy framework 
to improve targeting and consolidate social welfare programs, phase 2 will develop and implement 
tangible policy actions to achieve better targeting, which will ensure that the poor and vulnerable 
people  are  the  major  beneficiaries,  reduce  the  number  of  nonpoor  accessing  these  programs, 
and promote fiscal sustainability. These policy actions include (i) introducing poverty targeting to 
selected  social  welfare  programs;  (ii)  updating  the  poverty-targeted  integrated  household 
information  database  and  household  socioeconomic  survey;  and  (iii) applying  proxy  means 
testing to  programs  of  other government  agencies,  such  as the  Ministry  of  Justice,  which  was 
initiated under phase 1. 
 
15. 
In addition, phase 2 will develop and implement policy actions to support the consolidation 
of the 71 social welfare programs, which will help improve the efficiency and effectiveness of these 
programs. Under phase 2, the interministerial working group will be strengthened. The working 
group will (i) differentiate between the different programs in order to see more clearly where the 
duplication lies and analyze funding options; (ii) further analyze options and impacts of welfare 
benefit  consolidation;  (iii)  develop  an  action  plan  for  consolidation,  including  the  required 
amendments to the Social Welfare Law; and (iv) develop a communication strategy to raise public 
awareness  of  targeting  and  consolidation  changes.  Technical  assistance  support  will  also  be

consolidation of social welfare programs.16 
 
16. 
Alignment with government plan and the country partnership strategy. The program 
is  consistent  with  the  government’s  economic  recovery  program  and  the  IMF  program.  It  is 
consistent  with  ADB’s  interim  country  partnership  strategy  for  Mongolia,  2014–2016,    which 
highlights sustainable growth and inclusive social development as its main pillars.17 It is also in 
line  with  the  emphasis  on  inclusive  economic  growth  in ADB's  Strategy  202018  and  on  social 
protection in its midterm review.19 
 
17. 
Development partner coordination. ADB has been working closely with the IMF, World 
Bank, and Japan International Cooperation Agency during the preparation of this program. ADB 
has coordinated the proposed policy measures to avoid cross-conditionality and duplication. The 
IMF, the World Bank, and ADB will support measures to reduce the fiscal deficit progressively and 
strengthen the fiscal framework. ADB and the World Bank will support measures to improve the 
efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  social  welfare  programs  in  Mongolia.  The  IMF  will  support 
measures  to  improve  monetary  and  central  bank  governance. ADB,  IMF,  and  World  Bank  will 
support measures to strengthen the banking system and preserve financial stability. The World 
Bank and Japan International Cooperation Agency will support measures to improve governance, 
boost competitiveness, and diversify the economy. 
 
18. 
ADB’s value addition. Given  Mongolia’s  serious  internal  and external  imbalances,  the 
extended fund facility will involve fiscal and external policy adjustment that will further slow growth 
in 2017. Phase 2 of the Social Welfare Support Program will help mitigate the impact by protecting 
the budget for social welfare programs for the poor and vulnerable people. In addition, reforming 
a sensitive area like social welfare requires long-term effort and commitment. As highlighted in 
para. 9, ADB has been a long-term partner of Mongolia in helping the country reform its social 
welfare  system  since  2001.  Building  on  previous  ADB  assistance,  phase  1  of  the  program 
provided  a  systematic  and  holistic  way  to  improving  social  welfare  programs  in  Mongolia  by 
establishing the required policy framework. Phase 2 of the program will play an important role in 
deepening the reform agenda by implementing tangible policy actions to achieve a well-targeted 
and sustainable social welfare system in Mongolia. The government and development partners 
have also acknowledged that ADB, through phase 2 of the program, will play a lead role in helping 
the government to reform  social  welfare  programs  in  Mongolia.  Knowledge  and  understanding 
generated from both phases of the program can be shared with other, similar developing member 
countries. 
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

19.

consolidation  on  the  poor  and  vulnerable  people.  The  outcome  will  be  maintained  fiscal 
expenditure on social welfare programs for the poor and vulnerable people.

C. 

Outputs 

20. 
The outputs will be (i) improved fiscal policy management and (ii) improved policies and 
regulations to support targeting and consolidation of social welfare programs. The policy actions 
under the program are presented in Appendix 4. The first tranche of the program has 11 policy 
actions.  The  second  tranche  has  7  policy  actions.  The  program  will  be  implemented  over  19 
months, from 1 September 2016 to 31 March 2018. 
 
21. 
Output  1:  Improved  fiscal  policy  management. The  program  aims  to  improve  fiscal 
policy management in order to support fiscal sustainability of social welfare programs for the poor 
and vulnerable people in Mongolia. Policy actions to restore fiscal stability include (i) revising the 
Fiscal  Stability  Law  to  support  fiscal  consolidation  and  improve  debt  management,  and  (ii) 
eliminating  the  fiscally  unsustainable  Good  Programs.  Policy  actions  to  improve  budget 
transparency include (i) approving the 2017 supplementary budget consistent with the extended 
fund facility program targets, (ii) establishing the Future Heritage Fund and eliminating the Human 
Development Fund,20 and (iii) amending the Law on Development Bank of Mongolia in 2017 (to 
make  DBM  a  commercially  oriented  entity).  In  addition,  given  the  division  of  labor  among  the 
development partners, tranche 2 of the program will entirely focus on social welfare reform. The 
IMF will lead the fiscal consolidation component.

 Development Financing Needs 

D. 
 
24. 
The  government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $150  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources  to  help  finance  the  program.  The  loan  will  be  disbursed  in  two  tranches.  The  first 
tranche of $100 million will be withdrawn upon loan effectiveness as the first-tranche policy actions 
have been  satisfactorily  completed. The  second tranche  of  $50 million  will  be  withdrawn  upon 
achievement of the second-tranche policy actions. 
 
25. 
The loan will have a 15-year term, including a grace period of 3 years; an annual interest 
rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending 
facility; a commitment charge of 0.15% per year; and such other terms and conditions set forth in 
the draft loan and program agreements. Based on the straight-line method the average maturity 
is 9.25 years, and there is no maturity premium payable to ADB. 
 
26. 
The loan proceeds will be used to finance the full foreign exchange cost (excluding local 
taxes and duties) of items, excluding ineligible items and imports on the negative list attached to 
the loan agreement. The proceeds of the loan will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Loan 
Disbursement Handbook (2015, as amended from time to time).  
 
27. 
The program will support social welfare programs for the poor and vulnerable people that 
are  adversely  affected  by  the  economic  slowdown  and  fiscal  consolidation.  The  loan  size  is 
determined based on the percentage of social welfare benefits going to the poor (64%) multiplied 
by the 2016 social welfare budget ($230 million). Therefore, to protect the poor and vulnerable 
people, the government would require about $150 million. 
 
E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

28.  MOF will be the executing agency, overseeing and coordinating the timely implementation 
of  the  policy  actions.  The  MLSP  will  be  the  implementing  agency,  responsible  for  the 
implementation  of  policy  actions  relating  to  output  2  under  the  policy-based  loan. A  program 
steering committee, comprising senior representatives from MOF and MLSP, will be set up and 
chaired by the MOF secretary. The committee will meet quarterly to monitor progress under the 
program. ADB will assess program implementation through periodic progress reports submitted 
by MOF, and will field missions to confirm the fulfillment of policy actions for tranche releases.  
 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Economic 

29. 
The economic slowdown in Mongolia has widened the fiscal and current account deficits, 
increased the unemployment rate, reduced household income, and increased the prices of some 
goods  and  services.  For  instance, the  average monthly  household  income fell by  9% from  the 
same period a year earlier. This would have pushed a large percentage of people living just above 
the poverty line into poverty. Furthermore, fiscal consolidation would also entail cuts in the social 
welfare budget, which will severely affect the poor and vulnerable people because they depend 
heavily on welfare benefits for their daily subsistence.23 
 

                                                
23 Sector Assessment (Summary): Poverty and Social Impact Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents 

in Appendix 2).  

7 

 

 8 

 

30. 
The ADB support program will protect the budget for social welfare programs for the poor 
and vulnerable people. It also aims to improve the targeting and consolidation of social welfare 
programs to make them more effective and fiscally sustainable. Improved poverty targeting would 
mean that the nonpoor will not be able to access the social welfare programs that are currently 
targeted by category, particularly those programs that are merit-based rather than needs-based. 
Consolidating social welfare programs with overlapping purposes will also increase the efficiency 
and effectiveness of these programs. 
 
B. 

Governance 

31. 
Public  financial  management.  Pro-cyclical  fiscal  management,  optimistic  revenue 
forecast, and misalignment of public expenditure and strategic priorities are major public financial 
management challenges. To provide strategic guidance for the annual budget process and reduce 
vulnerability to the boom–bust economic cycle, the government introduced a 3-year, medium-term 
budget framework in 2003. However, this has not been effective because of poor windfall revenue 
management  and  frequent  amendments  affecting  budget  expenditure.  In  addition  to  greater 
countercyclical  fiscal  discipline,  budget  preparation  and  public  expenditure  need  to  be  better 
aligned with policy priorities. While the comprehensiveness of information included in the budget, 
its  public  disclosure,  and  citizen  participation  have  improved,  recent  increases  in  off-budget 
expenditures and the limited oversight of fiscal risks in state-owned enterprises, particularly DBM, 
would undermine this progress.24  
 
32. 
The  IMF-led  program  will  help  improve  public  financial  management  by  preventing  the 
government from engaging in quasi-fiscal activity, creating a fiscal council to provide independent 
budget forecasts and costings of new policy proposals, allowing the government sole authority to 
determine the total amount of spending in the budget, and granting MOF the authority to approve 
proposals to the cabinet that have a budgetary cost. 
 
33. 
Corruption. Mongolia has taken steps to improve accountability and transparency in the 
public sector. The Independent Authority Against Corruption has implemented public education 
campaigns. Reporting coverage of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative in Mongolia is 
also expanding. Despite these efforts, corruption continues to threaten the development of the 
Mongolian economy.25 Major corruption risks include weak institutions and enforcement, lack of 
capacity of integrity institutions, political interference, lack of transparency and accountability, and 
the  prevalence  of  conflicts  of  interest.  The  policy  actions  under  the  IMF-led  program  and 
monitoring  indicators  would  ensure  strict  compliance  with  the  program  objectives  and  thereby 
minimize  risks. ADB’s Anticorruption  Policy  (1998,  as  amended  to  date)  was  explained  to  and 
discussed with the government. 
 
C. 

Poverty, Social, and Gender 

34. 
Poor households are being affected by the economic slowdown through job losses, less 
purchasing capacity, and fewer income opportunities. Price inflation for some goods and services 
has  also  reduced  the  purchasing  power  of  these  households.  They  cope  by  reducing  food 
consumption and food quality, limiting health expenditures, and increasing debt. Many households 

                                                
24 Public Financial Management Performance (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2) and Risk 
Assessment  and  Risk  Management  Plan  (Summary)  government  assessment  prepared  as  part  of  the  country 
partnership strategy for Mongolia, 2017–2021. 

25 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (Summary) government assessment prepared as part of the country 

partnership strategy for Mongolia, 2017–2021. 

 increasingly rely on the regular payments from CMP and FSP for their basic needs.26 In addition, 
fiscal consolidation would reduce funding for social welfare programs. This would hurt the poor 
and vulnerable people, particularly women, because over 50% of the welfare beneficiaries are 
female.  

35. 
The program will support the social welfare budget for the poor and vulnerable people. 
Consolidation  of  social  welfare  benefits  can  help  reduce  administrative  burdens,  which  would 
particularly benefit women because they are responsible for much of the household interaction 
with social welfare offices. Moreover, MLSP is working to strengthen labor market programs that 
assist the poor and people working in temporary or seasonal jobs. Other partners, such as the 
World Bank and United Nations agencies, continue to provide technical assistance in this area. 
 
36.  Moreover,  economic  diversification  will  help  solve  the  issue  of  poverty  by  creating  new 
jobs. One of the key components of the IMF-led program is to help improve competitiveness and 
diversify the economy through the World Bank’s Development Policy Loan program, especially in 
agriculture,  trade,  and  business  environment.  Reforms  under  the  IMF-led  program  include  (i) 
improving  the  banking  system  to  ensure  that  the  banks  can  support  sustainable  and  inclusive 
economic growth,27 (ii) bolstering the investor protection council to foster investor confidence, (iii) 
strengthening the institutional framework to implement the trade facilitation agreement under the 
World  Trade  Organization,  and  (iv)  improving  animal  health  management  framework  through 
adopting Animal Health Law.28 
 
D. 

Safeguards 

37. 
The program activities are confined to policy reforms. None of the policy actions will result 
in or lead to involuntary resettlement or adversely affect indigenous peoples.29 The benefits will 
accrue  to  all  Mongolians.  No  adverse  environmental  impacts  were  identified.  The  program  is 
categorized C for environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples. 
 
E. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

38. 
The overall benefits of the program are expected to outweigh the costs. Major risks and 
mitigating  measures  are  summarized  in  the  following  table  and  described  in  detail  in  the  risk 
assessment and risk management plan.

Mitigating Measures 
Under the IMF-led program, the government is prevented 
from engaging in quasi-fiscal activity, a fiscal council will be 
created to provide independent budget forecasts and 
costings of new policy proposals, the government will have 
sole authority to determine the total amount of spending in 
the budget, and the Ministry of Finance will have the

budgetary cost. 
The policy actions under the IMF-led program and 
monitoring indicators will ensure strict compliance with the 
program objectives and thereby minimize risks. 
The program will be implemented in 2017, well ahead of 
the next general election. Continued engagement with the 
government and close interaction with the development 
partners minimize the impact of political risks 
Ongoing technical assistance by the Asian Development 
Bank and the World Bank will provide necessary support to 
overcome capacity limitations. 
The IMF-led program, supported by the large package of 
external financing, is expected to stabilize the economy 
and lay the basis for sustainable, inclusive, long-term 
growth. By 2019, growth is projected to pick up to around 
8%. Foreign exchange reserves are expected to be $3.8 
billion by the end of the program. 

IV. 

ASSURANCES  

39. 
The government has assured ADB that implementation of the program shall conform to all 
applicable  ADB  policies,  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards, 
gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as described  in  detail  in the  loan 
documents. The government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the program, which 
are set forth in the draft loan agreement. 
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

40. 
I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  policy-based  loan  would  comply  with  the  Articles  of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
loan of $150,000,000 to Mongolia for the Social Welfare Support Program Phase 2, from ADB’s 
ordinary  capital  resources,  with  interest  to  be  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London 
interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)  based  lending facility; for  a term  of  15-years,  including  a grace 
period of 3 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with 
those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board.
